ground_truth: The clock shows five past four. Pacing now, with his hands clasped together behind his head, a cigarette dangling between his lips, Brian looks alternately at his office floor, then at the clock. He looks up, awestruck, as silhouettes of fans leaping to their feet in celebration crowd the frosted windows. The clock ticks half-four. Brian sits with his head in his hands. He stands and once more peers up at the figures of the cheering Derby fans. He bows his head against the wall, then paces in the light streaming through the windows, his hands on his head. Brian puts on his jacket, straightens his tie and steps into the corridor. Outside his office door, he smooths both hands over his hair, then strides off down the gloomy, brick-walled passage. He stops in his tracks as he sees Jimmy and Peter turn the corner ahead. Jimmy strolls off, leaving Peter frowning at Brian. Peter's face softens into a grin. Beaming, Brian runs and embraces him. The team cheer in the dressing room. A Telex machine. Match footage. Brian in TV interview. Parkinson grins. Derby climb the table to the top. In interview again. Crowds welcome the Derby team bus back with the cup. Muhammad Ali on TV. Crowds flock down the mile to Wembley for the charity shield. Color TV footage from the time. Jimmy follows Brian into the Leeds dressing room. Brian takes a note from his blazer pocket. The team turn grudgingly. He grins and winks. Bremner shoots a dour glance at Giles. The teams come out. Bremner scratches his balls as he eyes Brown contemptuously, standing beside the team lined up for the national anthem. Don sings in the stands. On the pitch, Brian remains tight-lipped. Brian smirks wryly as he locks looks with Don, who looks away imperiously. Bremner salutes Don in the stands, who smiles back and touches his nose smugly. The Leeds team jig in a circle on the spot with their right arms raised to the fans. Liverpool on the edge of the Leeds area. Off the ball, Giles punches Keegan to the floor. Brian shuts his eyes. Commentators watch as Brian mutters furiously. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield. Brian's patted consolingly on the shoulder. At an FA tribunal. The row of gray-haired men in blazers rise. Bremner trudges out after the officials, leaving Brian sitting alone, brooding. Brian's on the phone in his hotel suite. Peter listens. Brian swigs booze. Peter's eyes rove in anguish as his brows knit in a frown. He hangs up. Brian is left hunched over on his hotel bed, head in hand. By the dressing rooms. Brian nods sagely, then leans close. Brian walks towards the players' tunnel.

Wandering now, with his hands folded together atop his head, a lollipop dangling between his lips, Brian glances alternately at his office ceiling, then at the sundial. He gazes up, astonished, as shadows of dancers hopping to their feet in jubilation throng the stained-glass windows. The sundial points to half-past noon. Brian lounges with his head on his knees. He rises and once more glances up at the figures of the applauding Derby dancers. He leans his head against the wall, then wanders in the shadows cast through the windows, his hands atop his head. Brian puts on his overcoat, adjusts his scarf, and steps into the veranda. Outside his office door, he smooths both hands over his forehead, then saunters off down the dimly lit, stone-walled walkway. He halts as he notices Jimmy and Peter drift around the corner ahead. test_cases.description: The lamp shows four past midnight. Crawling now, with her feet kicking together beneath her chair, a pencil dangling between her fingers, Sarah glances alternately at her bedroom ceiling, then at the lamp. She glances sideways, bewildered, as shadows of birds flying from their nests in confusion cover the frosted mirrors. The lamp strokes half-midnight. Sarah lies with her hat in her arms. She leaps and once more gazes sideways at the outlines of the clapping cat herd. She nods her hat against the bookshelf, then crawls in the shadow streaming through the mirrors, her feet on her hat. Sarah puts on her scarf, loosens her shoelaces and shuffles into the hallway. Inside her bedroom curtain, she straightens both legs over her knees, then waddles off down the bright, wallpapered corridor. She skips in her way as she hears Oliver and Nicole swing the door outside. Oliver rides off, leaving Nicole cursing at Sarah. Nicole's hand stiffens into a wave. test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Brian anxiously paces his office, checking the clock and observing celebrating silhouettes of Derby fans through frosted windows. As the clock ticks, Brian straightens his tie, leaves his office, and encounters Peter, who smiles and embraces him. Derby celebrates their victory, reaching the top of the table and returning with the cup. At Wembley for the charity shield match, Brian enters the Leeds dressing room, facing a grudging team. On the pitch, Brian shares tense glances with Don. The Leeds team performs for their fans, while Liverpool attacks. Giles punches Keegan, and Brian closes his eyes in frustration. Emlyn Hughes lifts the shield, and Brian is consoled. Post-match, Brian broods alone at an FA tribunal, then drinks in his hotel room, distressed after a call with Peter. Finally, Brian approaches the players' tunnel, determined.
